en.purpose: To support consistent documentation and decision support based on the Fuhrman Nuclear Grade for renal cell carcinoma. This archetype captures observed nuclear morphology and calculates the final tumor grade (1 to 4) used for prognosis and treatment planning.
en.use: Use to record nuclear diameter, nuclear shape, nucleolar prominence, and the presence of bizarre nuclei in cases of renal cell carcinoma. The recorded values are used to assign the final Fuhrman Nuclear Grade (1 to 4). This archetype supports clinical documentation, structured reporting, and integration with decision support logic.
en.misuse: This archetype should not be used for other tumor types or non-histologically confirmed diagnoses. It is not intended for pediatric use or cases where sufficient morphological data is not available. It should not replace clinical judgment in cases with ambiguous or mixed features.

other_details.en: The Fuhrman Nuclear Grade classification is used for determining the histological severity of clear cell renal cell carcinoma, where the grade is assigned based on nuclear diameter, shape, and nucleolar prominence.

gt0001.text: Fuhrman Nuclear Grade for Clear Cell Renal Carcinoma
gt0001.description: The Fuhrman Nuclear Grade is a histopathological classification system used to stratify the severity of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC). It assesses nuclear features across three criteria: size, shape, and nucleolar prominence, and assigns a grade from 1 to 4 based on the most severe observed feature.

gt0009.description: The nuclei of the tumor cells are small (< 10 µm), hyperchromatic, and round (resembling mature lymphocytes), with no visible nucleoli and little detail in the chromatin, as shown in the image below.

gt0014.text: Bizarre often multilobed nuclei and/or spindle cells

gt0017.description: Using the 10× objective, the nuclei of the tumor cells are slightly larger (15 µm) with finely granular “open” chromatin but small, inconspicuous nucleoli (see the following image). The nucleoli are often present, and many appear as small chromocenters at 10× objective, with confirmation of their nature at higher power, but this does not count.

gt0018.description: Using the 10× objective, the nuclei of the tumor cells are larger (20 µm in size) and may be oval in shape, with coarsely granular chromatin (see the image below). The nucleoli are easily unequivocally recognizable.

gt0019.description: The nuclei are pleomorphic with open chromatin or hyperchromatic and single or multiple macronucleoli]
